so_8107886: for f in *.zip; do unzip -d "${f%*.zip}" "$f"; done

Explanations about Options.-q:
perform operations quietly (-qq = even quieter). Ordinarily unzip prints the names
 of the files it's extracting or testing, the extraction methods, any file or
 zipfile comments that may be stored in the archive, and possibly a summary when
 finished with each archive. The -q[q] options suppress the printing of some or all
 of these messages.
Explanations about Options.-p:
extract files to pipe (stdout). Nothing but the file data is sent to stdout , and
 the files are always extracted in binary format, just as they are stored (no
 conversions).

Explanations about Options.--exclude: Exclude files matching PATTERN, a glob(3)-style wildcard pattern.
Explanations about Options.-c:
Create a new archive. Arguments supply the names of the files to be archived.
 Directories are archived recursively, unless the --no-recursion option is given.
Explanations about Options.-C:
Change to DIR before performing any operations. This option is order-sensitive,
 i.e. it affects all options that follow.
Explanations about Options.-x:
Extract files from an archive. Arguments are optional. When given, they specify
 names of the archive members to be extracted.

Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.

Top-3 Scripts:
ul_104208: find . -depth -type d -exec sh -c '
cd "$1" || exit
[ "$(ls ./*.txt 2>/dev/null)" ] &&
[ -z "$(ls -ad ./* | grep -v '\.txt$')" ] &&
(
  b=$(basename "$1")
  cd ..
  zip -r "$b.zip" "$b" && rm -rf "$b"
)' sh {} \;

ul_104208: folders=$(find . -type d -exec sh -c 'cd "$1";[ "$(ls *.txt 2>/dev/null)" ] \
          && [ -z "$(ls -ad * | grep -v '\.txt$')" ] && echo "$1"' sh {} \;)

echo "$folders" | zip -r@ archive && echo "$folders" | while read folder; do
  echo "will remove $folder"
  # Uncomment next line for the folder to be removed
  # rm -rf "$folder"
done

find . -depth -type d -exec sh -c '
cd "$1" || exit
[ "$(ls ./*.txt 2>/dev/null)" ] &&
[ -z "$(ls -ad ./* | grep -v '\.txt$')" ] &&
(
  b=$(basename "$1")
  cd ..
  zip -r "$b.zip" "$b" && rm -rf "$b"
)' sh {} \;

Explanations about Options.--block-size:

 format below
Explanations about Options.-a: do not ignore entries starting with .

so_66588884: /var/lib/work_directories/test

test/

$> tree test
test
├── a
├── b
└── c

$> zip -rj test.zip test
updating: a (stored 0%)
updating: c (stored 0%)
updating: b (stored 0%)

cd /var/lib/work_directories && zip -r test.zip test

updating: test/ (stored 0%)
  adding: test/a (stored 0%)
  adding: test/c (stored 0%)
  adding: test/b (stored 0%)

ul_528513: -m
   --move
          Move  the  specified  files  into the zip archive; actually, this deletes the target directories/files after making the specified zip archive. If a directory
          becomes empty after removal of the files, the directory is also removed. No deletions are done until zip has created the archive without error.  This is use-
          ful  for  conserving  disk  space, but is potentially dangerous so it is recommended to use it in combination with -T to test the archive before removing all
          input files.

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

ul_104208: folders=$(find . -type d -exec sh -c 'cd "$1";[ "$(ls *.txt 2>/dev/null)" ] \
          && [ -z "$(ls -ad * | grep -v '\.txt$')" ] && echo "$1"' sh {} \;)

echo "$folders" | zip -r@ archive && echo "$folders" | while read folder; do
  echo "will remove $folder"
  # Uncomment next line for the folder to be removed
  # rm -rf "$folder"
done

find . -depth -type d -exec sh -c '
cd "$1" || exit
[ "$(ls ./*.txt 2>/dev/null)" ] &&
[ -z "$(ls -ad ./* | grep -v '\.txt$')" ] &&
(
  b=$(basename "$1")
  cd ..
  zip -r "$b.zip" "$b" && rm -rf "$b"
)' sh {} \;

Explanations about Options.-v: Invert the sense of matching, to select non-matching lines.

au_587739: -n --no-name
          When  compressing,  do  not save the original file name and time
          stamp by default. (The original name is always saved if the name
          had  to  be  truncated.)  When decompressing, do not restore the
          original file name if present (remove only the gzip suffix  from
          the  compressed  file name) and do not restore the original time
          stamp if present (copy it from the compressed file). This option
          is the default when decompressing.
